Allegan Area Educational Service Agency
July 15 at 2:00 PM ·

Allegan Area ESA has three Headlee Restoration proposals on the August 4 ballot.

Proposal III: Career and Technical Education. This proposal will restore 0.0262 mills to return to the voter approved amount of 1.78 mills. These funds support the programs AAESA offers to at no charge to local districts (i.e. the Allegan Tech Center).

More information is available at www.alleganaesa.org/headlee
#theAAESAway

post_text:
Virtual Academy of Allegan County (VAAC)

The Virtual Academy of Allegan County (VAAC) is being designed in a collaborative effort among local, participating school districts to provide a 100% online educational option for students and families. It is important to note that this is vastly different from both a traditional in-person school experience and the spring 2020 emergency remote instruction. The VAAC provides online curriculum, interactive instruction and activities. There will be assessments and students will earn grades and credits as part of staying connected to their local district. If you are interested in potentially enrolling your child in VAAC please respond to this survey.

https://docs.google.com/forms/d/1f_v5DOiBzUJfjtF4F8Y0azL_qJgGQg2cAIKIKELyczI/viewform?edit_requested=true

Allegan Area Educational Service Agency
July 14 at 2:00 PM ·

Allegan Area ESA has three Headlee Restoration proposals on the August 4 ballot.

Proposal II: Special Education. This proposal will restore 0.0448 mills to return to the voter approved amount of 3.05 mills. These funds flow to local school districts to assist in offsetting the district’s state mandated, unreimbursed special education costs.

More information is available at www.alleganaesa.org/headlee
#theAAESAway

Allegan Area ESA has three Headlee Restoration proposals on the August 4 ballot.

Proposal I: Operating Millage. This proposal will restore 0.0262 mils to return to the voter approved amount of 0.14 mills. This millage supports local districts in Allegan County with AAESA consultants in math, science, and literacy.

More information is available at www.alleganaesa.org/headlee

post_text:
Hopkins Public Schools would like to ensure all of our students are healthy and have access to proper nutrition during the period when school is not in session March 16-April 3, 2020 due to the COVID-19 virus. We are able to provide meals at no cost during this emergency school closure. Meals will be available for pickup on Tuesdays and Fridays at the following locations and times.

10:30 a.m. Hopkins Fire Hall, St. Mary’s, and Watson Township Hall

11:30 a.m. Hilliards Corner, Burnips Township Hall, and Faith Baptist Church (125th)

12:15 p.m. Sycamore Elementary

12:30 p.m. Topaz Estates and Monterey Township Hall

1:00 p.m. Holiday Trailer Park

If you are interested in receiving FREE meals for your student(s) ages 18 and under, please complete the attached survey to help us organize our service to you. Each pick up will provide meals for multiple days.

Survey link: https://forms.gle/m293vdY87MS7xn5i9

post_text: Artwork created by HES Kindergartener, Kade Byville, was exhibited in the Michigan Visual Arts Celebration Feb. 7-12, 2020. Kade’s Art piece was chosen for further adjudication at the State Level! The Visual Arts Celebration, hosted by the GRAM, featured Artwork by K-8th grade students from 24 public and private schools in Region 9 of Michigan. Students and families were invited to tour the exhibit, and recognize the Artists at a reception on Thursday, Feb. 6. Artwork chosen by the next jury will participate in the State Show.
text: Artwork created by HES Kindergartener, Kade Byville, was exhibited in the Michigan Visual Arts Celebration Feb. 7-12, 2020. Kade’s Art piece was chosen for further adjudication at the State Level! The Visual Arts Celebration, hosted by the GRAM, featured Artwork by K-8th grade students from 24 public and private schools in Region 9 of Michigan. Students and families were invited to tour the exhibit, and recognize the Artists at a reception on Thursday, Feb. 6. Artwork chosen by the next jury will participate in the State Show.

post_text: Hopkins FFA Chapter hosted donkey basketball on Sat. Feb. 1 at the high school gym in order to raise money to help provide leadership development opportunities for our members. Four teams competed, including students, staff, FFA members, and the Hopkins Area Fire Department. Participants had to ride donkeys while playing basketball. Rules included you could not let your donkey go free, one person had to be on their donkey in order to pass, and you had to be on your donkey in order to shoot the ball. The HAFD were named the champions for the third time in a row! A huge thank you to all of our participants and all those who came out to enjoy the show!
shared_text:
Hopkins FFA
February 3 at 10:51 PM ·

Donkey Basketball (part 5)...Championship round...Students vs Fire Fighters

Congrats to the HAFD on keeping their winning streak going and being 3X Donkey Basketball Champions🎉🏀🏆🎉
text:
Hopkins FFA Chapter hosted donkey basketball on Sat. Feb. 1 at the high school gym in order to raise money to help provide leadership development opportunities for our members. Four teams competed, including students, staff, FFA members, and the Hopkins Area Fire Department. Participants had to ride donkeys while playing basketball. Rules included you could not let your donkey go free, one person had to be on their donkey in order to pass, and you had to be on your donkey in order to shoot the ball. The HAFD were named the champions for the third time in a row! A huge thank you to all of our participants and all those who came out to enjoy the show!

February 3 at 10:51 PM ·

Donkey Basketball (part 5)...Championship round...Students vs Fire Fighters

post_text:
Hopkins Got Talent--The Competition/Show Night is Fast Approaching!

The 2020 Hopkins Got Talent Competition is THIS WEEKEND
Saturday: January 18th at 7pm.
Location: Hopkins Middle School Cafeteria

Concessions will be available.

AUDIENCE VOTE DETERMINES THE WINNERS!

Audience Members also have the chance to WIN CASH AND PRIZES in our Minute to Win It Games (3 total games played throughout the evening)

Tickets:
$6 advanced tickets are ON SALE NOW in the Hopkins Middle School & High School offices
Tickets are $10 at the door the evening of the competition
Tickets are also available online (Credit Cards accepted) at https://Hopkins.ludus.com/5565
*Tickets purchased online will be printed and ready for pickup, under the name of the purchaser, at the ticket table on the evening of the show.

Come support our students/community members, vote for who YOU think deserves the $500 1st prize, win some money/prizes for yourself in our MTWI games, and help support our Vocal Music Department students with this "fundraiser in disguise" called Hopkins Got Talent!

post_text: “Homelessness is not a life sentence. In fact, it is a solvable problem. We have learned more in the past ten years about how to solve the homelessness problem than we did in the previous twenty to thirty years of providing maintenance for those people experiencing homelessness,” said David Pirtle.

post_text: November was first declared as National Homeless Youth Awareness Month in 2007. Since then, November has been a time to acknowledge those children and families experiencing homelessness. As many as 2.5 million youth per year experience homelessness. Along with losing their home, community, friends, and routines as well as their sense of stability and safety, many homeless youth are also victims of trauma.
text: November was first declared as National Homeless Youth Awareness Month in 2007. Since then, November has been a time to acknowledge those children and families experiencing homelessness. As many as 2.5 million youth per year experience homelessness. Along with losing their home, community, friends, and routines as well as their sense of stability and safety, many homeless youth are also victims of trauma.

post_text:
Third graders at Hopkins Elementary participated in the Bonnie Plants' Third Grade Cabbage Program this summer. Students received a giant-variety cabbage plant from Bonnie Plants, as well as instruction from the Hopkins FFA School Garden team to grow the biggest cabbage they could. The Hopkins FFA provided an additional incentive of an M-89 Cinema gift card and goody pail for the Hopkins student with the largest cabbage. Congratulations to Cole Erickson, whose cabbage weighed in at over thirteen pounds! Cole will also be entered in Bonnie Plants' national scholarship competition for the largest cabbage nationwide.

Third graders continue to learn science lessons in the school garden this fall with the Hopkins FFA School Garden team.
text:
Third graders at Hopkins Elementary participated in the Bonnie Plants' Third Grade Cabbage Program this summer. Students received a giant-variety cabbage plant from Bonnie Plants, as well as instruction from the Hopkins FFA School Garden team to grow the biggest cabbage they could. The Hopkins FFA provided an additional incentive of an M-89 Cinema gift card and goody pail for the Hopkins student with the largest cabbage. Congratulations to Cole Erickson, whose cabbage weighed in at over thirteen pounds! Cole will also be entered in Bonnie Plants' national scholarship competition for the largest cabbage nationwide.

Third graders continue to learn science lessons in the school garden this fall with the Hopkins FFA School Garden team.

post_text: This year the band is excited to present the music from The Greatest Showman with The Main Theme to The Greatest Showman, A Million Dreams, This Is Me, Never Enough, and From Now On. We will be featuring soloists Colby Robbe and Kenton Landrigan on trombone, Celina Hamilton on piccolo, Chad Steffes on tuba, Hunter Collison and Olivia Barry on mellophone, and Alex DeGraves on trumpet. This year the band is performing at marching festival, 3 marching invitationals, and 3 home football games.
text: This year the band is excited to present the music from The Greatest Showman with The Main Theme to The Greatest Showman, A Million Dreams, This Is Me, Never Enough, and From Now On. We will be featuring soloists Colby Robbe and Kenton Landrigan on trombone, Celina Hamilton on piccolo, Chad Steffes on tuba, Hunter Collison and Olivia Barry on mellophone, and Alex DeGraves on trumpet. This year the band is performing at marching festival, 3 marching invitationals, and 3 home football games.

post_text:
ACT – Allegan County Tours for Freshmen
The Allegan Area STEM Partnership, AAESA, and local district volunteers, are coordinating a countywide effort to provide two employer tours to every Allegan AESA district freshman during the month of October. This project is an attempt to provide an intentional progression of experiences for students to explore various career paths, employment opportunities in the Allegan County region, and to help districts meet the Michigan Career Development requirements. In this inaugural year, there are 1,150 freshmen students from 10 schools in Allegan County participating.
text:
ACT – Allegan County Tours for Freshmen

In this inaugural year, there are 1,150 freshmen students from 10 schools in Allegan County participating.

post_text: The high school band wrapped up the school year with their Memorial Day performances. We visited both Maplewood and Poplar hill and spent time remembering those who gave their lives for our country and fought for our freedom. We were honored to perform the National Anthem and the piece In the Shining of the Stars. Senior trumpet player Laura Velderman also performed taps for the ceremonies and it was covered by the news! Such a beautiful way to end a great year!
text: The high school band wrapped up the school year with their Memorial Day performances. We visited both Maplewood and Poplar hill and spent time remembering those who gave their lives for our country and fought for our freedom. We were honored to perform the National Anthem and the piece In the Shining of the Stars. Senior trumpet player Laura Velderman also performed taps for the ceremonies and it was covered by the news! Such a beautiful way to end a great year!

post_text: Hopkins 7th & 8th Grade Band students performed at Michigan's Adventures on May 31st this year. They performed three pieces for the crowds while they worked their way through the main gate. They then got to enjoy the part for about 5 hours after lunch. It was a beautiful day for the park! The combined group of around 70 7th and 8th grade students had a blast!

post_text:
Attention Bridge Card Holders:
Double Up Food Bucks will be back at your area's farmers' markets. When you use your Bridge Card at a participating farmers' market, the Double Up Food Bucks program will match you dollar for dollar with bonus funds - up to $20 - that you can use in the market to buy more fresh, Michigan-grown fruits and vegetables.
www.doubleupfoodbucks.org
www.westmichiganfarmmarkets.org

DOUBLEUPFOODBUCKS.ORG
Double Up Food Bucks
text:
Attention Bridge Card Holders:
Double Up Food Bucks will be back at your area's farmers' markets. When you use your Bridge Card at a participating farmers' market, the Double Up Food Bucks program will match you dollar for dollar with bonus funds - up to $20 - that you can use in the market to buy more fresh, Michigan-grown fruits and vegetables.
www.doubleupfoodbucks.org
www.westmichiganfarmmarkets.org

Double Up Food Bucks

post_text: This morning, the state released the cut scores for 3rd grade reading proficiency. The good news for Hopkins is that if the law had been in effect for our most recently assessed third graders, none of our students, district-wide, would be subject to the retention policy. This is the result of the hard work and dedication of our outstanding staff and the interventions that have been put in place over the past few years.
